Description: Large shoulder and body fragment (mended from two sherds) of North Ionian black-figured pottery krater; interior reserved except for band at top of sherd; exterior, whitish slip: chain of incised lotus flowers and buds on black ground above the main decorated field with added white paint (now mostly worn off); below, two confronted lions attacking a boar facing right; filling ornaments: rosettes, dotted rosettes and strokes; patches of added red on parts of lions and boar; incision used for details of lions, boar. Drill hole from sampling for analysis on broken edge.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
"Naukratis 1899" marked on the inside. For similar vessels see British Museum GR 1886,0101.1123, 1926,1117.3, 1965,0930.297 and Walter-Karydi 1973, pl. 115 no. 941.
Alexandria 9522 is probably from same vessel.
Bibliographic references: Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (p. 191, fig. 18) (only G119.43 illustrated)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (II D, pl. IV, 21)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.507)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.701, table 8.18, no.8)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
